text.headline: Oops Timeline
text.text:
Statements, laws enacted, executive orders, rulings,
and policy decisions that may have been regretted ☞

text.headline: WHO Claim: No clear evidence of human to human
text.text: "No clear evidence of human to human " - clipped from WHO tweet.

text.headline: Claim: US Declines offer to expand N95 manufacture
text.text: "January [2020], Department of Health and Human Services officials effectively dismissed an offer from one of America’s few remaining N95 manufacturers, Prestige Ameritech, to expand its production lines". New York Times article via @AbraarKaran

text.headline: Dr David Powell (IATA medical adviser): "Forget Masks"
text.text: International Air Transport Association has a physician as a medical advisor, David Powell. He gave a video interview for Bloomberg and suggested that masks did a "better job of spreading bugs than preventing them". By May 5th, Powell would change to promote mask use on board planes

text.headline: Dr Nathalie MacDermott: "no evidence surgical masks can protect the general public"
text.text: Dr Nathalie MacDermott, a clinical lecturer at King's College London, told Sky News there is "not any good evidence" to suggest surgical masks can protect the general public from the virus but there are other methods

text.headline: Instruction: US citizens should stop buying masks as they are "not effective"
text.text: The tweet was later deleted, but on this day Surgeon General for the USA, Jerome Adams, claimed that masks were ineffective. On video a month later, he showed the world how to make masks from T-Shirts (apology in kind). When Joe Biden became the 46th president, Adams was asked to hand in his resignation. Adams hasn't accounted for what happened leading up to the regrettable tweet, but he may do so in the fullness of time.

text.headline: BBC TV: Dr Shunmay Yeung (LSHTM) says masks don't work
text.text: Dr Shunmay Yeung from London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine (LSHTM) in BBC TV interview says (incorrectly ) that masks don't work because "It's not protecting me because it's not there [in the air]."

text.headline: WHO expert Tweet: COVID-19 is not Airborne
text.text: Maria Van Kerkhove (@mvankerkhove on Twitter), Infectious Disease Epidemiologist and COVID-19 Technical Lead for the World Health Org's Health Emergencies Programme: "COVID-19 is not Airborne". See also related tweet.

text.headline: Belgium: Destroy millions of masks at the the start of the pandemic
text.text: Belgium’s current health ministry destroyed millions of mouth masks it had in a strategic reserve stock because they reached their expiration date, but failed to replace them

text.headline: WHO Tweet:  "FACT: #COVID19 is NOT airborne"
text.text: A tweet incorrectly saying COVID19 is not airborne and prmoting distance and fomites only was pushed out on Twitter and promoted by WHO staff following that.

text.headline: Swedish Folkhalsomynd:  "face masks are not needed in in the community"
text.text: Swedish Folkhalsomynd: "Do face masks protect against transmission? [...] However, face masks are not needed in in the community"

text.headline: UK: Up to 1st lockdown, UK quarantines only 273 of 18.1m air passengers
text.text: The UK government insisted that the scientific advice showed that placing restrictions at the border would not have had a significant impact on the spread of the virus in the UK. Their first lockdown was the 16 March, 2020. See also No 'patient zero' as Covid-19 came into UK at least 1,300 times

text.headline: USA: Beloved supermarket Trader Joe's fires employee for asking for better staff protection
text.text: Store responds in detail to an employee, Ben Bonnema's, letter pleading for better #COVIDisAirborne protections and policies, nixing their chance of claiming a generic "staff cuts" excuse later: See Twitter thread. Corporate in a statement a day later: "We have never, and would never, terminate a Crew Member's employment for raising safety concerns," adding "store leadership terminated this Crew Member's employment because of the disrespect he showed toward our customers." March 4th: TJ's rehires Ben.
